title: 105_hr4123
content: The Act may be cited as the "Retirement Savings Assistance Act" and involves amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes provisions for additional salary reduction catch-up contributions. The "Retirement Savings Assistance Act" includes provisions for additional catch-up contributions for individuals approaching retirement or who have been unemployed and out of the workforce. Individuals aged 35-49 who have not participated in a retirement plan in the past five years can make catch-up contributions of $2,000 annually until age 50. Those aged 50 and above can also make additional catch-up contributions. The Retirement Savings Assistance Act allows for catch-up contributions for individuals aged 35-49 who have not participated in a retirement plan in the past five years. They can contribute $2,000 annually until age 50. Individuals aged 50 and above can also make additional catch-up contributions. The Retirement Savings Assistance Act allows individuals aged 35-49 who have not participated in a retirement plan in the past five years to contribute $2,000 annually until age 50. Those aged 50 and above can make additional catch-up contributions of $10,000. The Retirement Savings Assistance Act allows individuals aged 35-49 who have not participated in a retirement plan in the past five years to contribute $2,000 annually until age 50. The Retirement Savings Assistance Act allows individuals aged 35-49 to contribute $2,000 annually until age 50. Those aged 50 or older can make catch-up contributions of $10,000. Amendments apply to plan years starting after December 31, 1998. SEC. 3. INCREASE IN OVERALL AND "AFTER TAX" CONTRIBUTION LIMIT. Increase in Limit: The dollar limit for defined contribution plans is increased from $30,000 to $40,000. Cost-of-living adjustments are also amended to reflect this change, with the repeal of the 25 percent limit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the dollar limit for defined contribution plans from $30,000 to $40,000. Various sections of the Code are amended to reflect this change, including adjustments to exclusion allowances and contribution amounts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the dollar limit for defined contribution plans from $30,000 to $40,000. Section 415(c) is amended by removing paragraph (4) and updating section 415(c)(7) regarding contributions by church plans. The organization described in section 414(e)(3)(B)(ii) sets a $10,000 annual limit on contributions for annuity contracts or retirement income accounts under section 403(b). The total aggregate limit for any participant over all years is $40,000. The term "annual addition" is defined in paragraph (2). Section 415 of the Code is amended to remove certain provisions and adjust percentages. These amendments will apply to years starting after December 31, 1998.
